Project.Brief history of your project and organi: The Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites (GOES) program, began in 1975 with GOES-1 to provide continuous weather and environmental data for the Western Hemisphere. The modern GOES-R Series, launched between 2016 and 2024, features advanced imaging technology for high-resolution weather monitoring every 30 seconds to 10 minutes. Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service (NESDIS), the program supports forecasting, disaster response, and climate research.
Project.Describe the data being stored onto File: The Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites (GOES) program stores high-resolution satellite imagery and meteorological data. This includes full-disk and regional imagery from GOES-16, 17, 18, and 19, captured every 30 seconds to 10 minutes across 16 spectral bands in NetCDF format. The data supports real-time weather monitoring, severe storm tracking, and environmental research across the Western Hemisphere. It is accessible via Open Data Dissemination on AWS S3 and formatted for efficient storage and retrieval.
Project.How do you plan to prepare the dataset: To prepare the Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites (GOES) dataset, we first download the data from AWS S3 using the AWS CLI, verifying integrity to check file metadata without downloading contents. The dataset, comprising high-resolution multi-spectral imagery and meteorological data, is segmented into chunks using go-graphsplit, with files split into smaller parts and packaged into CAR files, each assigned a unique PieceCID. Metadata, including file sizes, split counts, and spectral band details, is stored in a PostgreSQL database for indexing and efficient retrieval.
Project.In which geographies do you plan on maki: Australia (continent), Asia other than Greater China, Greater China, Africa, North America, South America, Europe
